title: @Riot, could you stop giving us 3 Air Dragons in a row?
body:
Whenever an Air Dragon spawns, the general mentality seems to be "Gee, that sucks. Hope the enemy team clears it quickly so we can get a useful dragon next." This mentality seems to be mirrored by the other team, which results in the Dragon sticking around uncontested for a long time (20 minutes in my last game).

But you know what makes it worse? When one team finally caves and decides to clear the stupid thing, only to have another Air Dragon set to take its place.

You know what makes *that* worse? You guessed it, going through the whole process of waiting, one team giving in and clearing it, and a *third* Air Dragon being set to spawn.

It's at this point that the only dragon that can come next is the Elder Dragon, because everything has taken so long. Guess what? Even teams without a Dragon to their name at this point value the Elder Dragon, not as a denial, *but as something actually decent to spawn in that pit!*

Had a game where the Jungler was AFK at about the 20 minute mark, but thankfully we didn't need to care about securing Dragons because they were all Air Dragons. If that's intentional, then great, but if not, can Air Dragon please be made into something useful?

A hyper-rare, hyper-powerful dragon spawn would be incredibly swingy and every game it appears in would just come down to who gets the dragon at that moment instead of all the things that are supposed to matter in a game of league.

If the team that's behind gets it well good for them, they're back in the game but it's one sided as stated above.

There are 2 problems with just amping the effect with Air:

 - Diminishing returns after you hit the 415 ms cap, which in the current season is hella common and ordinary

- If lets say you want to rotate quickly to a sidelane in order to utilize the effect, nothing will happen if there isnt a minion wave close to the enemy tower

Solutions i would propose:

- Increase the ms cap or lower the overall mobility in the game (changes to items basically)

- Make Air an aura that affects nearby allied minions

- Your ideas about river speed etc are also good

Mobis give 90 MS for just spending 600 gold (I'm assuming Brown Boots are a given). When you fight for Air Drake, the story goes, there's supposed to be combat; the other team is going to try to stop you, or take it themselves. And the Drake itself is probably going to do some pittance of damage. And it detracts from time you could be spending doing something useful. And after all that, if you've put in the time, effort, and risk, you get...NOT EVEN FUCKING CLOSE TO THE AMOUNT FROM MOBIS

Mobis also take up your boot slot, preventing you from buying any other kind of boots.  Dragons don't take up inventory slots.

Also, 600 gold per person is *way* more than old dragon, so I don't see why you'd be surprised that a new dragon is less powerful than that.  3k from a single objective would be nuts; even baron power plays don't always top that and that's including baron itself *plus* collecting standing gold.  3k worth of stats *that don't even take up inventory space* would be beyond nuts.

In fact, if you consider mobis as the baseline for valuing out of combat movespeed, then one air drake is worth 1/4 of mobis, or 150 gold per person, about as much as the old dragons.

Fighting in the pit doesn't seem to be any harder than fighting under an enemy turret and possibly easier.  And the enemy doesn't automatically have vision as soon as you start your attempt.  A tower, also, is worth way less than upgrading everyone on the team's boots (to any version).

I think the key here is that Cloud Drake is consistently viewed as by far the weakest variant, and almost not even worth taking unless it's completely free.  

It's very possible this is just a perception problem, but it's hard to pit 15 flat Movement Speed against 4% missing health and mana sustain.  The value for the second is just so much higher when considering the visibility and noticeable impact, Cloud can't even compare.

We've been looking into the dragon buffs a lot this weak and come to the conclusion that, overall at high skill play, they're very close in power. Statistically each of the four buffs has a period in the game where it's strongest, in terms of influence on your chance to win. Air's power's harder to track, and therefore take deliberate advantage of/play against though, which means it doesn't feel as good as the others tend to. We're going to keep looking at the four buffs, particularly in pro play since we usually see the most organized teams there, to see what opportunities there are to improve each of them. Overall though it doesn't look like it would be appropriate to make air feel better using raw power though.

Okay, now how about at medium to low skill play? 

I don't want to get into the whole 'which playerset to balance towards?' debate, and I understand that dragons, as a neutral objective that are not necessary to win the game, are generally a coordination thing over anything else, and as such are better appreciated by more coordinated teams, but I get kinda pissy if changes are made for a playerbase that I'm not in, especially massive, gamechanging stuff like dragon changes.

High skill in this context's actually just the top third of the player base (not top third of ranked, but all games, which equates to somewhere in Silver upwards from memory). You personally are certainly in the group dragons are being balanced for as a result, though yeah, the discussion of who to balance for in general's a pretty complex one. 

We don't have a good read yet on buff performance in what a lot of people define as 'high skill' (pro play or high diamond plus), so it's not yet clear how air performs in those circumstances overall. That's on our list of things to look at, we can't balance solely for that skill level though certainly.

...Right. Sorry, I honestly keep forgetting most people are in silver and below.

Generally, the problem with air is that it is, basically, the one that requires effort. Even if you're a bunch of badly coordinated randoms, you can use fire, water, and earth, because they're just passive boosts. Sure, you might not use them optimally, but anyone can use plus AD/AP.

Air, on the other hand, requires coordination to make useful. Out of combat move speeds only matters for roaming and getting back to lane, and given how often roaming is hard if you can't trust your laners, having a dragon be 'you get back to lane faster' is immensely disappointing.

Yeah, air does demand more execution to get its benefit. I suspect we might see its effectiveness increase slightly over time as a result as people get more familiar with it.

Statistically Earth and Water also show noticeably increased power with skill level, given the need to poke/delay and focus on objectives respectivelly. Fire's the strongest by a noticeable margin in a context where 'run straight into a full on fight with the enemy' is really common.

Hell, even if I'm playing a roam heavy, rotation heavy champion, air is a disappointment. Everything's a disappointment next to fire, really.

Are you looking at adding Pre game Champ select icons denoting the three Types of dragons that will spawn (not which order just type) to allow teams to have a bit more decision making in champ select so that a team can't get lucky and be a MS/Roam based team and get lucky with a dragon type that is great for them but does next to nothing for the enemy team? (this is a mostly moot point) It would be interesting to see what the addition would change in the professional play level for champion selections based on knowing the dragons that are going to be in the game.

I somewhat agree, and somewhat disagree, because it technically wouldn't have an impact on champion select other than to say what a team could plan for, but if a team can recognize that the enemy team would want to take a dragon that synergizes, then regardless, it would be in the team's best interest to take the dragon whether they can use it or not just to deny it. (That was my disagree).

On the flip side it could potentially continuously shift through several different groupings of champions (at pro play) in which the teams would be focusing around taking dragons in their comps, and since only 3 can spawn in a game, that leaves 4 combinations, so 4 groups of champions (probably a small batch) with several very strong and/or very consistent champions.

From a design perspective though, I don't know if it would work. Most things in the gamespace (in a vacuum) are constant except for the dragons now. The idea in champion select is to build against your opponents and attempt to beat them with bans and picks. Adding the dragons may dilute that by getting teams to instead build around the dragons that will spawn instead of around their opponents/teammates. It also may not be possible (no idea, it depends on how Riot set up the client and PvP.net) to set this up to begin with since the dragons might not have even been selected when champion select comes around. They may be determined right when the match begins.

I get Tempo.  Which is why a lot of Dragons only fall to who ever has Bottom on a Lane Swap, while Rift goes to who ever took Top in a Lane Swap.  It's an easy flow to the Objective without having to commit extra Resources because the Resources were already used to be there for the Turret in the first place.

But what people are saying is that Cloud Drake is literally ignored... which means it can be Solo Killed by your Jungle.  Because if they send Resources to stop it... then they aren't taking advantage of you being at Dragon, they are instead reacting to your play.  So either they Respond, in which case they lose the advantage  stop you from getting an advantage, or they stay and push while you Solo Cloud Drake.

Take the Objective... for a reaction, and if no reaction occurs take the free gift.

Ignoring the Cloud Drake, if you consider it useless, just means the Enemy Team never has to respond to your threat of taking Cloud Drake... because you never threaten it.   So they get to continue to push what ever advantage they may be looking for instead of having to adjust to your actions.

Also, ignoring Cloud Drake means you are delaying the time until you see a Drake you might actually consider a priority.

Before you get to 4th and 5th Dragon, most of the Dragons aren't even really contested anymore at Pro Level Play... because they don't want to run head first into an Engagement that they weren't already in proper position for.  If they are 'Late' they simply concede and move to another objective.

The issue is that it is *not* uncontested.

The very act of taking an objective like dragon carries risk. It's an objective that both teams keep warded (even in my low level, normals games it's *always* warded). If you go for it, you're letting the enemy know that you'll be in a space that's easy for them to surround and force you into a team fight you may not want or be ready for. 

**Dragon is a non-essential objective; it has nothing to do with winning the game on its own. Fire dragon and Earth dragon at least help you take objectives that actually matter, fire dragon also helps you win fights, and water dragon kinda sorta helps you siege or heal up after a good fight to keep pushing. Air dragon does nothing to affect structures and literally stops working during the most important phase of the game - actually fighting for towers and inhibitors needed to win. *Air dragon is not worth dying for and risking the enemy snowballing and/or taking towers while you're waiting to respawn.***
